item.title: Prakrit
item.description: Source: here. hattha=hand bahira=outside vahu=son’s wife kOra=horse tObI=washer kANI=story pai=brother lihai=write suha=happiness sAhA=branch maueda=crown kayala=plantain koha=anger meha=cloud dIva=island vihalai=split subha=good makkaDa=monkey Naha=nail The Dravidian language Tamil retains a large number of old loans from Maharashtri Prakrit, even though its descendent language Marathi does not. This suggests that the prakritic base of other IA languages were overlayed by a secondary layer derived from a later degeneration of Sanskrit. This secondary layer is actually a Pan-Indian phenomenon and could represent the point of normalization of the Pan-Indian Sanskritic elite with respect to the Prakritic masses.
